item.title: Bypass Windows Defender Using Go Buena CLR
item.description:
Bypassing Windows Defender for .NET Malware with Go-Buena-CLR

Windows Defender, with its Anti-Malware Scan Interface (AMSI), poses a formidable challenge for .NET-based malware developers. However, the evolving landscape of offensive security continuously introduces innovative techniques to bypass these defenses. This post explores how to use Go-Buena-CLR, a custom CLR host written in Go, to effectively bypass Windows Defender‚Äôs AMSI and execute .NET malware without detection.

Why Bypass AMSI for .NET?

AMSI is a security interface that allows Windows Defender and other anti-malware solutions to inspect scripts and code loaded into memory, making it a primary target for bypass techniques. For .NET malware, AMSI can easily flag suspicious assemblies, preventing execution. Our method leverages Go-Buena-CLR, a custom CLR host that allows .NET binaries to run without triggering AMSI‚Äôs detection.
